A good introductory course for beginners who have no idea what vectors and linear equations are. But as most of the engineers already took it at High School, you could go through it quickly. I found it more beneficial to read through the topics rather than going through the videos as it helped to revise the entire thing in an hour. It should be easy to follow!!
HI Tatev.  Awesome course.  Was great review for me, since it's been more than 25 years I took linear algebra and calculus. :)  You are Turkish or Armenian?

With only good intention, I mean a good mood too, As a teacher of maths I must say your intro is too long. You should start sooner and the program of contents must be available as a list in the comments (a static one fixed at the top).You may add some dynamic video than that (I only achieved 48 minutes and quit watching, I'm sorry). It could be warmer for viewers to see the teachers face from time to time. Besides write better. Human brains (most of them) learn in an easily way if reading or watching something well structured (please, write better). Mathematician is not a bad writer.
Thanks!

This is the superficial Linear Algebra that is taught to engineering students and maybe CS majors. To anyone that is truly curious, I recommend you learn Proofs and then learn Linear Algebra again from the proofs perspective. Linear Algebra is really important, it is the foundational language used in AI, many engineering disciplines, Computer Vision, Graphics, and perhaps most importantly Quantum Mechanics.
What's her OF?

Well not if you just want to revise it after years, or if you are not from the engineering background. For example I'm 4th year CS major. I learnt this in 1st year. I don't have to neither do I want to learn it from scratch, just as a refresher, even these 6 hours are a lot. But I can skip and cherry pick. And for people not from engineering background they won't understand proofs anyway, they would be more interested in the applicable gist.

Some of the chapter's timestamps appeared to be a bit off, I've attempted to correct/adjust them below:         "Introduction to the course": "00:00:00",         "Linear Algebra Roadmap for 2024": "00:08:30",         "Course Prerequisites": "00:27:50",         "Refresher: Real Numbers and Vector Spaces": "00:34:15",         "Refresher: Norms and Euclidean Distance": "00:38:30",         "Why These Prerequisites Matter": "00:52:13",         "Module 1: Foundations of Vectors": "00:51:28",         "Vector - Geometric Representation Example": "00:56:49",         "Module 2: Special Vectors": "01:22:23",         "Application of Vectors": "01:35:01",         "Vectors Addition and Subtraction": "01:47:13",         "Properties of Vectors Addition": "02:03:51",         "Module 3: Advanced Vectors and Concepts": "02:19:15",         "Scalar Multiplication":"02:20:25",         "Scalar Multiplicaton Examples":"02:24:46",         "Scalar Multiplication Application":"02:29:34",         "Module 4: Dot Product and Its Applications":"02:44:21",         "Length of a Vector - def and example": "02:49:14",         "Length of Vector - Geometric Intuition": "02:54:33",         "Dot Product": "03:05:31",         "Dot Product, Length of Vector and Cosine Rule": "03:20:00",         "Cauchy Schwarz Inequality - Derivation & Proof": "03:29:15",         "Introduction to Linear Systems": "03:41:30",         "Introduction to Matrices": "03:57:19",         "Core Matrix Operations": "04:13:28",         "Solving Linear Systems - Gaussian Elimination": "05:19:14",         "Detailed Example - Solving Linear Systems": "05:25:01",         "Detailed Example - Reduced Row Echelon Form (Augmented Matrix,REF, RREF)": "05:35:52"
Thank you. Start of lessons 34:16
